Wages do not adjust for inflation in the year after a negative monsoon rainfall shock.
Effects of negative monsoon rainfall shocks on agricultural wages are near-permanent. We set value to -1 because wages are decreased.
Rice prices increase in the year of the monsoon rainfall shock. We set value to 1 because prices are increased.
Rice prices remain above pre-shock trend. We set value to 1 because prices are increased.

Reflects an increase in rabi (winter) crop production profiting from additional water supply caused by above-average monsoon rainfall in the kharif season. Values are declines.
Illustrated response is negative.
Illustrated response is positive.
Labourers and cultivators both reduce staple food consumption expenditures on impact; analysis includes endogenous response in consumption expenditures. 1998 is the midpoint of the 1989-2006 period.
Drought leads to a fall in real consumption. Coded as -1 to indicate reduction.
Drought leads to reduced consumption expenditure on staple foods, especially for agricultural laborers, lasting several years. Coded as -1 to indicate reduction.
Drought leads to a persistent decline in agricultural wages. Coded as -1 to indicate reduction.
Yield falls by up to 30% after a regional drought, depending on the local extent of irrigation.
Yield falls by up to 15% after a local drought, depending on the local extent of irrigation.
Wages fall by up to 7% with the peak decline occurring two years after the drought and lasting up to five years.
Food prices immediately rise by up to 5 percent, and remain at elevated levels for up to two years.
